Instrument.name: The Alice Ultraviolet Imaging Spectrograph for New Horizons
Instrument.description: The New Horizons Alice Ultraviolet Imaging Spectrograph is a lightweight (4.4 kg), low-power (4.4 Watt) imaging spectrograph aboard the New Horizons mission to Pluto/Charon and the Kuiper Belt. Its primary job was to determine the relative abundances of various species in Pluto's atmosphere by measuring emissions (in airglow mode) or by observing the Sun or bright stars through the atmosphere (occultation mode). Alice was and is used to search for atmospheres around all targets encountered, and also makes ultraviolet (UV) surface reflectivity measurements of all bodies encountered. The instrument incorporates an off-axis telescope feeding a Rowland-circle spectrograph with a 520-1870A spectral passband, a spectral point spread function of 3-6A FWHM, and an instantaneous spatial field-of-view that is 6 degrees long. Different input apertures that feed the telescope allow for both airglow and solar occultation (SOCC) observations during the mission. The focal plane detector is an imaging microchannel plate (MCP) double delay-line detector with dual solar-blind opaque photocathodes (KBr and CsI) and a focal surface that matches the instrument's 15-cm diameter Rowland-circle.
